overview: The purpose of this Act is to make the women's court pilot program in the first circuit permanent. [11] The Act will establish a three-year women's court pilot program in the circuit court of the Kona division of the third circuit, which is intended to acknowledge the distinct pathways that lead women into the criminal justice system and address their individualized needs. [11] This measure also requires the judiciary to submit a report to the legislature regarding the need for and the associated costs of a pilot program for women's court in the second and fifth circuits and Hilo division of the third circuit. [11]
appropriations: There is appropriated out of the general revenues of the State of Hawaii the sum of $ (HB727_SD2) or so much thereof as may be necessary for fiscal year 2025-2026 and $ (HB727_SD2) or so much thereof as may be necessary for fiscal year 2026-2027. [11] The Committee has amended this measure by changing the appropriations to unspecified amounts to facilitate further discussion on the measure. [12] The sums appropriated shall be expended by the judiciary for the purposes of this Act. [11]
assumptions_and_methodology: The Judiciary's proposed budget estimates the cost for a three-year pilot project would be $514,000 (HB727_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt) for fiscal year 2025-2026, $547,000 (HB727_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt) for fiscal year 2026-2027, and $515,000 (HB727_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt) for fiscal year 2027-2028. [10] A cost-savings analysis notes the cost of incarceration of just one person for three years is $277,035.10 (HB727_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt), based on an average cost of $253 (HB727_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt) per day. [10] [10] The Department of Health requests a budget of $221,788 (HB727_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt) to support the Kona division pilot project, based on the Department’s staffing requirements for the operation of the existing Women’s Court pilot project of the First Circuit. [10]
agency_impact: There shall be established within the third circuit Kona division of the judiciary the women's court pilot program, which shall be under the supervision of the big island drug court. [11] The Department of Health's role has been to provide screening and assessments of possible eligible participants for the program, including forensic mental health consultation and coordination. [10] The Department of Health requests $221,788 (HB727_SD2_SSCR1531_.htm.txt) to support the Kona division pilot program for a Clinical Psychologist and a Social Worker or Human Services professional. [12]
economic_impact: The goal of the pilot program is diverting participants from incarceration, supporting their success in the community, and reducing recidivism. [11] The cost of incarceration of just one person for three years is $277,035.10 (HB727_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt). [10] If the Kona Women's Court helps keep just six women out of prison, the program will have already paid for itself. [10]
policy_impact: This Act makes the women's court pilot program in the first circuit permanent by amending Act 243, Session Laws of Hawaii 2022, to remove its repeal date. [11] It establishes a three-year women's court pilot program in the circuit court of the Kona division of the third circuit. [11] The Judiciary is also required to submit a report on the need for and associated costs of a pilot program in the second and fifth circuits and Hilo division of the third circuit. [11]
revenue_sources: The bill appropriates funds out of the general revenues of the State of Hawaii. [11] The sum of $ (HB727_SD2) is appropriated for fiscal year 2025-2026. [11] The sum of $ (HB727_SD2) is appropriated for fiscal year 2026-2027. [11]
six_year_fiscal_implications: The Judiciary's proposed budget for the three-year Kona pilot project is a total of $1,576,900.00 (HB727_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt). [10] The requested costs are $514,900.00 (HB727_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt) in Year 1, $547,000.00 (HB727_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt) in Year 2, and $515,000.00 (HB727_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt) in Year 3. [10] Annual recurring costs include $175,000.00 (HB727_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt) for a Women's Mental Health Professional, $100,000.00 (HB727_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt) for Womens Behavioral Health Beds, $85,000.00 (HB727_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt) for a Kona Drug Court Probation Supervisor, and $80,000.00 (HB727_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt) for a Peer Specialist. [10] [10] Additional services include a Cultural Practitioner and Advisor for $30,000.00 (HB727_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt) annually, Moral Reconation Therapy for $25,000.00 (HB727_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt) annually, and Increased Drug Testing for $10,000.00 (HB727_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt) annually. [10] [10] One-time costs in the proposal include $5,000.00 (HB727_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt) for training in Year 1, $42,000.00 (HB727_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt) for training in Year 2, and $4,900.00 (HB727_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt) for technology in Year 1. [10] [10] There is also a proposed cost of $10,000.00 (HB727_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt) for Program Evaluation in Year 3. [10] Part III of the Act, establishing the Kona pilot, shall be repealed on June 30, 2028. [11] Making the First Circuit program permanent will create ongoing fiscal obligations, though specific amounts are not detailed. [11]
operating_revenue_impact: The documents do not describe any anticipated impacts on operating revenues. [11] The program is supported by appropriations from the general revenues of the State of Hawaii. [11] There is no indication that the program will generate its own revenue stream. [11]
Full_Time_Equivalent_Positions: The bill provides for the establishment of two temporary positions. [11] This includes one full-time equivalent (1.0 FTE) Kona drug court probation supervisor position and one full-time equivalent (1.0 FTE) peer specialist position. [11] The Department of Health also requests funding for one full-time equivalent (1.0 FTE) Clinical Psychologist at a cost of $145,000 (HB727_SD2_SSCR1531_.htm.txt) and one full-time equivalent (1.0 FTE) Social Worker or Human Services professional at a cost of $76,788 (HB727_SD2_SSCR1531_.htm.txt). [12]
capital_expenditure_impact: The measure does not appropriate funds for major capital expenditures. [11] The Judiciary's testimony includes a breakdown of estimated technology costs totaling $4,900.00 (HB727_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt). [10] These costs include a Computer Workstation for $1,200.00 (HB727_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt), a computer for the Kona Probation Supervisor for $1,000.00 (HB727_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt), and a printer for $1,000.00 (HB727_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt). [10]
fiscal_implications_after_6_years: The Act makes the women's court pilot program in the first circuit permanent, which will result in ongoing fiscal obligations beyond the six-year timeframe. [11] Part III of the Act, which establishes the three-year women's court pilot program in the Kona division of the third circuit, shall be repealed on June 30, 2028. [11] Any fiscal implications for the Kona program beyond this date would require further legislative action. [11]
updates_from_previous_fiscal_note: The primary update is that the specific appropriation amounts have been removed from the bill. [11] The previous fiscal note cited specific appropriations of $514,900 for FY 2025-2026 and $557,000 for FY 2026-2027. [12] The Committee on Ways and Means has amended this measure by changing the appropriations to unspecified amounts to facilitate further discussion. [12] The Department of Health's request for $221,788 (HB727_SD2_SSCR1531_.htm.txt) for two positions to support the pilot program is explicitly noted in the new committee report. [12]
